section.heading: Section 16 of the Succession (Scotland) Act 1964

p.mod:
In section 16 (provisions relating to leases) of the Succession (Scotland) Act 1964 (c. 41)(in sections 21 to 23 referred to as “the 1964 Act”), after subsection (4) there is inserted—
(4A)
Where an interest, being an interest under a lease constituting a short limited duration tenancy or a limited duration tenancy—
(a)
is not the subject of a valid bequest by the deceased; or
(b)
is the subject of such a bequest, but the bequest is not accepted by the legatee; or
(c)
is the subject of such a bequest, but the bequest is declared null and void by virtue of section 21 of the 2003 Act,
and there is among the conditions of the lease (whether expressly or by implication) a condition prohibiting assignation of the interest, the executor shall be entitled, notwithstanding that condition, to transfer the interest to a person to whom subsection (4B) below applies; and the executor shall be entitled so to transfer the interest without the consent of the landlord.
(4B)
This subsection applies to—
(a)
any one of the persons entitled to succeed to the deceased’s intestate estate, or to claim legal rights or the prior rights of a surviving spouse out of the estate, in or towards satisfaction of that person’s entitlement or claim; or
(b)
any other person.
(4C)
In the case of any interest under a lease constituting a short limited duration tenancy or a limited duration tenancy—
(a)
if at any time the executor is satisfied that the interest cannot be disposed of according to law and so informs the landlord, the executor may terminate the tenancy (in so far as it relates to the interest); and
(b)
if the interest is not so disposed of within the period referred to in subsection (4D) below, the lease shall (in so far as it relates to the interest) terminate at the expiry of the period,
notwithstanding any provision in the lease, or any enactment or rule of law, to the contrary effect.
(4D)
The period is one year or such longer period as may be fixed by agreement or, failing agreement, by the Land Court on the application of the executor—
(a)
in the case of an interest which is the subject of an application to that court by virtue of section 21 of the 2003 Act, from the date of the determination or withdrawal of the application; and
(b)
in any other case, from the date of death of the deceased.
(4E)
The—
(a)
interest may be transferred under subsections (4A) and (4B) above; or
(b)
tenancy may be terminated under subsection (4C)(a) above,
only if the transfer, or as the case may be, termination is in the best interests of the deceased’s estate.
.

section.heading: Bequest of lease

content.p: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the tenant of a short limited duration tenancy , a limited duration tenancy, a modern limited duration tenancy or a repairing tenancy may, by will or other testamentary writing, bequeath the lease constituting the tenancy to any one of the persons mentioned in subsection (1A) .

intro.p: The persons referred to in subsection (1) are—

content.p: any person who would be, or would in any circumstances have been, entitled to succeed to the tenant's estate on intestacy by virtue of the Succession (Scotland) Act 1964,
a spouse or civil partner of a child of the tenant,
a spouse or civil partner of a grandchild of the tenant,
a spouse or civil partner of a brother or sister of the tenant,
a brother or sister of the tenant's spouse or civil partner,
a spouse or civil partner of such a brother or sister,
a child (including a step-child) of such a brother or sister,
a grandchild (including a step-grandchild) of such a brother or sister,
a step-child of the tenant,
a spouse or civil partner of such a step-child,
a descendant of such a step-child,
a step-brother or step-sister of the tenant,
a spouse or civil partner of such a step-brother or step-sister,
a descendant of such a step-brother or step-sister.

intro.p: Sections 11(2) and (3), 12A, 12B and 12C(1) and (2) of the 1991 Act apply in relation to subsection (1) as they do in relation to section 11(1), subject to the following modifications—

content.p: in section 11(2), the words “of a holding” and “of the holding” are omitted,
in section 12A, in subsections (3)(b) and (c) and (4)(b), for “holding” substitute “land comprised in the lease”,
in section 12C, in subsection (1), for “holding” substitute “land comprised in the lease”.

If the person to whom the lease is so bequeathed does not accept the bequest, or if the bequest is declared null and void by virtue of subsection (2), the right to the lease is, subject to section 16(4A) to (4E) of the 1964 Act, to be treated as intestate estate of the deceased in accordance with Part I of that Act.

section.heading: Right of landlord to object to acquirer of tenancy

content.p: A person to whom a lease constituting a short limited duration tenancy , a limited duration tenancy, a modern limited duration tenancy or a repairing tenancy is transferred under section 16 (provisions relating to leases) of the 1964 Act must give notice of the transfer to the landlord within 21 days of the transfer or (where that is not possible) as soon as practicable thereafter; and the lease is, subject to subsections (2) and (3), binding on the landlord and that person as landlord and tenant respectively as from the date of the transfer if such notice is given.

intro.p: Sections 12A, 12B and 12C(1), (2) and (5) of the 1991 Act apply in relation to subsection (1) as they do in relation to section 12(1), subject to the following modifications—
in section 12A—

content.p: in subsection (2), the reference to notice given under section 12(1) is to be read as a reference to notice given under subsection (1),
in subsections (3)(b) and (c) and (4)(b), for “holding” substitute “land comprised in the lease”,
in section 12B(2), the reference to notice given under section 12(1) is to be read as a reference to notice given under subsection (1),
in section 12C, in subsection (1), for “holding” substitute “land comprised in the lease”.

intro.p: Where a lease constituting a short limited duration tenancy , a limited duration tenancy, a modern limited duration tenancy or a repairing tenancy is transferred to a person under subsections (4A) and (4B)(b) of section 16 of the 1964 Act, the landlord is entitled to acquire the person’s interest in the lease provided that—
the landlord gives the person notice—

content.p: in writing; and
within 30 days of the giving of the notice under subsection (1),

wrapUp.p: of the landlord’s intention to acquire that interest; and

content.p: the terms upon which the landlord acquires that interest are no less favourable to the person than any reasonable terms upon which the lease was transferred to the person.

section.heading: Effect of termination of tenancy where tenant deceased

intro.p: Termination of a short limited duration tenancy , a limited duration tenancy, a modern limited duration tenancy or a repairing tenancy by virtue of—

content.p: section 16 of the 1964 Act; or
section 22,

wrapUp.p: is to be treated, for the purposes of any compensation payable under this Act, as termination at the expiry of the term of the tenancy.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Registration of interest and the right to buy

section.heading: The Keeper and the Register

content.p: For the purposes of this Part, “the Keeper” is the person who keeps the Register of Community Interests in Land (in this Part referred to as “the Register”) under section 36 (Register of Community Interests in Land) of the Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 2).
The Keeper is to keep the Register so that there is contained in it a part for registering tenants' interests in acquiring land in accordance with section 25.

intro.p: There is to be included in that part of the Register—

content.p: a record of any notice or notification sent to the Keeper under any provision of this Part; and
where a registration of a tenant’s interest in acquiring land is removed under section 25(15), an entry specifying the date on which that is effected.

section.heading: Registration of tenant’s interest

content.p: A tenant of a 1991 Act tenancy may apply to have registered an interest in acquiring the land comprised in the lease by sending a notice (in this section referred to as a “notice of interest”) to the Keeper.

intro.p: For the purposes of this Part, “tenant”—

content.p: where there are two or more tenants under the lease, means those tenants; and
does not include a sub-tenant.

intro.p: The notice of interest must be in such form as the Scottish Ministers may prescribe by regulations and must specify—

content.p: the particulars of the tenant and the owner of the land;
where there are two or more tenants under the lease, the fact that each of them consents to the making of the application to register their interest in acquiring the land;
the location and boundaries of the land (by reference, where appropriate, to the lease or any map or drawing);
any interest or rights comprised in the land (including any sporting or mineral rights); and
such other information as the Scottish Ministers may so prescribe.
The tenant must send a copy of the notice of interest to the owner of the land and notify the Keeper that the copy has been so sent.

intro.p: On receipt of the notice of interest, the Keeper must—
register—

content.p: the tenant’s interest in acquiring the land;
the details specified in the notice of interest; and
the date of registration; and
send an extract of the registration to the tenant and the owner of the land.

intro.p: Where the registration relates to land over which there is a standard security, the owner, on receipt of the extract, must—

content.p: intimate that fact to the tenant; and
send a copy of the extract to the creditor in the standard security.

intro.p: The Keeper may charge such reasonable fee for—

content.p: registering tenants' interests in acquiring land; and
providing extracts, and copy extracts, of registration,

wrapUp.p: as the Scottish Ministers may by order specify.

content.p: If the owner of the land disputes any matter contained in the extract of registration, the owner may, by notice in writing to the Keeper, challenge the registration of the tenant’s interest in acquiring the land on the grounds that any matter contained in the extract is inaccurate.

intro.p: On receipt of notice under subsection (8), the Keeper is to make such enquiry in connection with the tenant’s interest in acquiring the land as the Keeper considers appropriate; and following such an enquiry, if the Keeper considers that the notice of interest is inaccurate, the Keeper—

content.p: must, if the inaccuracy is material, rescind the registration of the tenant’s interest; and
may, if the inaccuracy is not material, amend that registration.

intro.p: Where, under subsection (9)—

content.p: the registration of the tenant’s interest in acquiring the land is rescinded, the Keeper must intimate that fact to the tenant and the owner of the land; and
that registration is amended, the Keeper must send an extract of the registration to the tenant and the owner of the land.

The tenant or the owner of the land may appeal to the Land Court against any decision made, following notice under subsection (8), by the Keeper in respect of the registration of the tenant’s interest in acquiring the land; and in an appeal under this subsection the Court may make such order as it considers appropriate.

intro.p: A registration of a tenant’s interest in acquiring land—

content.p: continues to have effect only in relation to such land as remains comprised in the tenancy; and

intro.p: ceases to have effect—

content.p: if the registration is rescinded;
if the tenancy is terminated; or
where neither of those things has occurred, at the expiry of the period of five years from the date of registration.

intro.p: Where—

content.p: the tenancy is terminated during that period; or,
there is a reduction in the land comprised in the tenancy,

wrapUp.p: the landlord must give notice in writing of that fact to the Keeper.

content.p: Where a tenant’s interest in acquiring land is, or has been, registered, the tenant may at any time apply to have the interest registered again (with or without modification to the matters specified in the notice of interest).
The Keeper must remove from the Register any registration of a tenant’s interest in acquiring land which no longer has effect.

section.heading: Notice of proposal to transfer land

intro.p: Where the owner of land in respect of which a tenant’s interest in acquiring land is registered under section 25 or a creditor in a standard security with a right to sell the land proposes to transfer the land or any part of it to another person, the owner or, as the case may be, the creditor must, subject to section 27—

content.p: give notice in writing of that fact to the tenant; and
send a copy of the notice to the Keeper.
Notice under subsection (1) must be given in accordance with such provisions (including provisions as to the form of the notice) as the Scottish Ministers may prescribe by regulations.

section.heading: Transfers not requiring notice

intro.p: Notice is not required under section 26 where the transfer is or, as the case may be, would be—

content.p: otherwise than for value;

in implement or pursuance of an order of a court (other than an order under section 24 of the Conveyancing and Feudal Reform (Scotland) Act 1970 (c. 35) or a decree in an action for the division and sale of land);
between spouses in pursuance of an arrangement between them entered into at any time after they have ceased living together;
of croft land to the crofter tenanting it;
between companies in the same group;
to a statutory undertaker for the purpose of carrying on the undertaking;

intro.p: a transfer—

content.p: implementing the compulsory acquisition of land under any enactment;
by agreement, of land which could have been acquired compulsorily under any enactment;
implementing any right conferred by Part 2 (which provides for the community right to buy) of the Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2003 (asp 2) to buy land;
implementing any right conferred by Part 3 (which provides for the crofting community right to buy) of that Act to buy eligible land within the meaning of that Part of that Act;

implementing missives for the sale and purchase of land concluded, or an option to acquire land which existed on a date on which no notice of interest in acquiring the land was registered under section 25;
which requires, or which but for the provisions of section 14 of that Act would require, the consent of the Scottish Ministers under subsection (5) or (7) of section 12 of that Act;
by a registered social landlord (within the meaning of the Housing (Scotland) Act 2010 (asp 17) ) in pursuance of the power conferred by section 107 of that Act;
vesting the land in a person for the purposes of any enactment relating to sequestration, bankruptcy, winding up or incapacity or to the purposes for which judicial factors may be appointed; or

intro.p: a transfer of land in consequence of—

content.p: the assumption or resignation or death of one or more of the partners in a partnership; or
the assumption or resignation or death of one or more of the trustees of a trust.

intro.p: In the case of a transfer mentioned in any of paragraphs (a), (e) and (h) of subsection (1), if the transfer—

content.p: is or forms part of a scheme or arrangement or is one of a series of transfers; and
the main purpose or effect, or one of the main purposes or effects, of the scheme, arrangement or, as the case may be, series is the avoidance of the requirements or consequences of this Part,

wrapUp.p: the transfer is, for the purposes of section 28, deemed to be a transfer in respect of which notice is required under section 26.

content.p: For the purposes of subsection (1)(e), companies are in the same group if they are, or are included in a number of, companies which, by virtue of section 170 of the Taxation of Chargeable Gains Act 1992 (c. 12), together form a group for the purposes of sections 171 to 181 of that Act.
In subsection (1)(f), “statutory undertaker” is to be construed in accordance with section 214 of the Town and Country Planning (Scotland) Act 1997 (c. 8).
The Scottish Ministers may by order modify (any or all) subsections (1) to (4).

section.heading: Right to buy

intro.p: Where a tenant’s interest in acquiring land is for the time being registered under section 25 and—

content.p: the owner of the land or a creditor in a standard security with a right to sell the land, gives notice to the tenant under section 26 of a proposal to transfer the land or any part of it; or

intro.p: the owner or the creditor takes any action with a view to the transfer of the land or any part of it and—

content.p: the transfer is a transfer in respect of which notice to the tenant is required under section 26; and
such notice has not been given,

wrapUp.p: the tenant has the right to buy the land to which the transfer relates (including any interest or rights comprised in the land) from the owner or, as the case may be, the creditor.

intro.p: Where—

content.p: a tenant has a right to buy land under subsection (1); and
despite the existence of that right, the owner, or as the case may be, the creditor transfers the land to a person other than the tenant,

wrapUp.p: the tenant has the right to buy the land (including any interests or rights comprised in the land) from the person to whom the land is transferred or is subsequently transferred.

intro.p: For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), action is taken with a view to a transfer of land when—

content.p: the land is, by or with the authority of the owner of the land or a creditor in a standard security with a right to sell the land, advertised or otherwise exposed for sale;
the owner or the creditor, or a person acting on behalf of the owner or the creditor, enters into negotiations with another person with a view to the transfer of the land; or

the owner or the creditor, or a person acting on behalf of the owner or the creditor, proceeds further with any proposed transfer of the land which was initiated prior to the date on which the notice of interest was registered.
References in subsection (3) to the owner of land include references to the person in whom it has vested for the purposes of any such enactment as is mentioned in section 27(1)(g)(ix).
The Scottish Ministers may by order modify (either or both) subsections (3) and (4).

section.heading: Exercise of right to buy

content.p: Where a tenant has a right to buy land under section 28(1), the tenant may proceed in accordance with section 32 to buy the land from the owner or, as the case may be, the creditor provided that notice is given under subsection (2).

Notice is given under this subsection if the tenant, within 28 days of receipt of the notice under section 26, gives notice to the owner or, as the case may be, the creditor that the tenant intends to buy the land.

Where a tenant has a right to buy under section 28(2), the tenant may proceed in accordance with section 32 to buy the land from the person to whom the land has been transferred or subsequently transferred provided that notice is given under subsection (4).

intro.p: Notice is given under this subsection if—

content.p: the tenant gives notice to that person that the tenant intends to buy the land; and
the notice is given within three years from the transfer to that person,

wrapUp.p: and the tenancy is in force on the date on which the notice is given.

content.p: If, at any time, the tenant does not intend to proceed, in accordance with section 32, to buy the land, the tenant is to give notice of that fact to the person from whom the land would otherwise have been bought.

intro.p: Where the tenant—

content.p: does not give notice in accordance with subsection (2) or, as the case may be, (4); or
gives notice under subsection (5),

wrapUp.p: the right to buy is extinguished.

content.p: A tenant giving any notice under this section must send a copy of the notice to the Keeper.

section.heading: Meaning of “creditor in a standard security with a right to sell land”

intro.p: Any reference in this Part to a creditor in a standard security with a right to sell land is a reference to a creditor who has such a right under—

content.p: section 20(2) or 23(2) of the Conveyancing and Feudal Reform (Scotland) Act 1970 (c. 35); or
a warrant granted under section 24(1) of that Act.

section.heading: Effect of extinguishing of right to buy

intro.p: Where a right to buy land is extinguished under section 29(6) or 32(8), the tenant may acquire a subsequent right to buy the same land or any part of it under section 28(1), but only if—

content.p: the period of 12 months from the extinguishing of the right to buy has expired; or

intro.p: before that period has expired—

content.p: the land is transferred to another person; and
that person requires to give notice under section 26 in relation to a subsequent transfer.

section.heading: Procedure for buying

content.p: It is for the tenant to make the offer to buy in exercise of the tenant’s right to buy under section 28.

intro.p: The offer is to be at a price—

content.p: agreed between the tenant and the person from whom the land is to be bought (“the seller”); or

intro.p: where there is no such agreement—

content.p: payable by the tenant in accordance with section 34(8); or
if the price is determined in an appeal under section 37, as is so determined,

wrapUp.p: and must specify the date of entry and of payment of the price in accordance with subsection (3).

intro.p: The date of entry and of payment of the price are to be—

content.p: a date not later than 6 months from the date when the tenant gave notice under section 29(2) or (4) of the tenant’s intention to buy;

intro.p: where the price payable by the tenant is the subject of an appeal under section 37 which has not, within the period of 4 months after the date when the tenant gave such notice, been—

content.p: determined; or
abandoned following agreement between the tenant and the seller,

wrapUp.p: a date not later than 2 months after the appeal is so determined or, as the case may be, abandoned; or

content.p: such later date as may be agreed between the tenant and the seller.
The offer may include such other reasonable conditions as are necessary or expedient to secure the efficient progress and completion of the transfer.

If the tenant has not, within the period fixed by or agreed under subsection (3), done any of the things mentioned in subsection (6), the seller may apply to the Land Court for an order under subsection (7).

intro.p: The things are—

content.p: concluding missives with the seller for the sale of the land to the tenant; or
if the tenant has not so concluded missives, taking all steps which the tenant could reasonably have taken in the time available towards so concluding missives.

intro.p: An order under this subsection may—
direct the tenant—

content.p: to conclude missives with the seller within such period; and
to take such remedial action for the purpose of so concluding missives; and
direct the tenant and seller to incorporate into the missives any term or condition in respect of the sale of the land,

wrapUp.p: as the order may specify.

intro.p: If—

content.p: the tenant fails to comply with an order under subsection (7); or

where the seller has not applied for an order under that subsection, the tenant has not (having regard to the period fixed by or agreed under subsection (3)) within a reasonable period from the acquiring by the tenant of the right to buy otherwise concluded missives with the seller for the sale of the land to the tenant,

wrapUp.p: the right to buy is extinguished.

section.heading: Appointment of valuer

content.p: Where the price is not agreed between the seller and the tenant, the land is, except where subsection (2) applies, to be valued by a valuer appointed by agreement between the seller and the tenant or by a person nominated by them.

This subsection applies where the land in respect of which the tenant is exercising a right to buy forms part of an estate comprising other land in respect of which any other tenant has given notice under section 29(2) or (4) of the tenant’s intention to buy.

intro.p: Where subsection (2) applies, the land mentioned in that subsection is to be valued by a valuer appointed by agreement between—

content.p: the seller; and
at least half of the tenants mentioned in that subsection,

wrapUp.p: or by a person nominated by them.

content.p: Where there is no agreement as to the appointment of a valuer under subsection (1) or (3), the valuer is to be appointed by the Land Court or by a person nominated by the Court.
In this Part, “valuer” includes two valuers with an oversman.

section.heading: Valuation of the land

content.p: The valuer appointed under section 33 is to assess the value of the land in respect of which the right to buy is being exercised as at the date of notice under section 26 of the seller’s proposal to transfer the land.

intro.p: The valuer is to assess the value of the land—
having regard to the value that would be likely to be agreed between a reasonable seller and buyer of such land—

content.p: assuming that the seller and buyer are, as respects the transaction, willing; and
where the buyer is a sitting tenant;

taking account, in so far as a seller and a buyer of the land (assuming that they are, as respects the transaction, willing) would do so, of any factor attributable to the known existence of a person who (not being the tenant who is exercising a right to buy the land) would be willing to buy the land at a price higher than other persons because of a characteristic of the land which relates peculiarly to that person’s interest in buying it;
taking account of when the seller would in the normal course of events have been likely to recover vacant possession of the land from the tenant;
taking account of the terms and conditions of any lease of sporting interests affecting the land;

intro.p: taking account of any moveable property belonging to the owner of the land which is, by agreement between the tenant and the owner, to be—

content.p: sold with; and
valued along with,

wrapUp.p: the land;

intro.p: taking no account of—

content.p: the absence of the period of time during which the land would, on the open market, be likely to be advertised and exposed for sale; or
any factor attributable to any use of the land which is or would be unlawful;
taking no account of any increase in the value of the land resulting from improvements carried out at the expense of the tenant;

taking no account of any increase in the value of the land resulting from the use of any of the land, or changes to the land, for a purpose that is not an agricultural purpose or the carrying out of conservation activities on the land;

intro.p: taking no account of—

content.p: any reduction in the value of the land as a result of any dilapidation or deterioration of, or damage to, fixed equipment or land caused or permitted by the tenant; or
any such reduction resulting from the use of any of the land, or changes to the land, for a purpose that is not an agricultural purpose or the carrying out of conservation activities on the land; and
taking no account of any fixed equipment owned by the tenant.

intro.p: For the purposes of subsection (2)(g)—

content.p: subject to paragraph (b), “improvements” is to be construed by reference to Schedule 5 to the 1991 Act; and

the continuous adoption by the tenant of a standard of farming or a system of farming more beneficial to the land than the standard or system required by the lease or, in so far as no system of farming is so required, than the system of farming normally practised on comparable agricultural land in the district, is to be treated as an improvement executed at the tenant’s expense.

intro.p: Where land in respect of which the right to buy is being exercised forms part of an estate, the valuer is, in addition to assessing the value of the land under subsection (2), to assess the value representing the difference between—

content.p: the value of the estate were the estate being sold by the seller to a person other than the tenant; and

the value of the remainder of the estate (that is to say, the estate less the land in respect of which the right to buy is being exercised) were the remainder being sold by the seller to such a person.

For the purpose of valuation under subsection (4), where two or more parts of an estate are being bought in exercise of a right to buy under this Part, the valuer may apportion to each such part of the estate (or re-apportion if for any reason the sale of any such part does not proceed) such amount representing the reduction in the value of the estate as the valuer considers equitable.
The Scottish Ministers may issue guidance (either generally or in respect of a particular class of case) for the purposes of valuation under this section.

intro.p: An estate is to be treated, for the purposes of subsections (4) and (5), as comprising—

content.p: any land forming part of the estate and which is being bought in exercise of a right to buy under this Part; and
any other land forming part of the estate offered for sale by the seller at the same time as the land mentioned in paragraph (a).

intro.p: For the purposes of section 32(2)(b)(i), the price payable by a tenant is—

content.p: the value assessed under subsection (2); or

intro.p: where the land forms part of an estate, the greater of the values assessed under—

content.p: that subsection; and
subsection (4).

section.heading: Special provision where buyer is general partner in limited partnership

intro.p: Where the person exercising a right to buy under section 28 is doing so by virtue of section 72(2)—
the valuer, in assessing the value of the land under subsection (2) of section 34, is to have regard to—

content.p: the fact that the buyer is a general partner of a limited partnership; and
any provision of the partnership agreement entitling a limited partner to dissolve the partnership; and
paragraph (a)(ii) of that subsection is of no effect.

section.heading: Valuation etc.: further provision

intro.p: The valuer is—
to invite—

content.p: the seller and the tenant; and
where the land forms part of an estate, any other person the valuer considers to have an interest in the estate,

wrapUp.p: to make written representations about the matters mentioned in subsection (2); and

content.p: to have regard to any such representations.

intro.p: The matters are—

content.p: the valuation of the land; and
where the land forms part of an estate, any valuation of the estate (and any apportionment of a reduction in the value of the estate),

wrapUp.p: under section 34.

intro.p: The valuer may—

content.p: enter onto land; and
make any reasonable request of the seller and tenant,

wrapUp.p: for the purposes of any assessment under section 34.

content.p: The valuer must, within 6 weeks of being appointed, send to the seller and the tenant a notice in writing specifying the price payable by the tenant under section 34(8) and setting out how the price was calculated.

intro.p: The expenses of the valuer accrued in carrying out the valuer’s functions under section 34 and this section are to be—

content.p: met by the tenant; or
where subsection (2) of section 33 applies, shared equally between the tenants mentioned in that subsection.

intro.p: Where—

content.p: the Land Court has made an order under section 32(7);
the tenant to whom the order applies has complied with the order; and
the seller does not proceed with the sale of the land to the tenant,

wrapUp.p: the seller is liable to the tenant for any expenses met by the tenant by virtue of subsection (5).

content.p: The Scottish Ministers may by regulations make further provision for or in connection with the matters provided for in this section and sections 33 and 34.

section.heading: Appeal to Lands Tribunal against valuation

content.p: The seller or the tenant may appeal to the Lands Tribunal against the valuation carried out under section 34.
An appeal under this section must state the grounds on which it is being made and must be lodged within 21 days of the date of the notice under section 36(4).

intro.p: In an appeal under this section, the Lands Tribunal may—

content.p: reassess any value of the land (and any factor affecting the value) or of an estate (and how any reduction in the value of an estate is to be apportioned); and
for the purposes of section 32(2)(b)(ii), determine the price.
The valuer whose valuation is appealed against may be a witness in the appeal proceedings.

intro.p: In the appeal proceedings, in addition to the seller and the tenant, the following persons are entitled to be heard—
where the seller is—

content.p: a creditor in a standard security, the owner of the land; and
the owner of the land, any creditor in a standard security over the land or any part of it; and

intro.p: where the land forms part of an estate—

content.p: any creditor in a standard security over; and
any tenant of,

wrapUp.p: any other land forming part of the estate.

content.p: The Lands Tribunal is to give reasons for its decision on an appeal under this section and is to issue a written statement of these reasons.
The decision of the Lands Tribunal in an appeal under this section is final.
In this section and section 38, “the Lands Tribunal” means the Lands Tribunal for Scotland.

section.heading: Referral of certain matters by Lands Tribunal to Land Court

content.p: Where, in an appeal before the Lands Tribunal under section 37, an issue of law arises which may competently be determined by the Land Court by virtue of the 1991 Act or this Act, the Tribunal is to refer the issue to the Land Court for determination unless the Tribunal considers that it is not appropriate to do so.

hcontainer.name: crossheading
hcontainer.heading: Application to Land Court for order for sale

section.heading: Application to Land Court for order for sale

intro.p: This section applies where—

content.p: the Land Court has made an order (but not an interim order) under section 84(1)(b) requiring the landlord of a 1991 Act tenancy to remedy a material breach of the landlord's obligations in relation to the tenant, or
an arbiter appointed under section 61A(3) of the 1991 Act has by virtue of section 61A(5) made an award having the same effect as such an order.

intro.p: Subject to subsection (5), the tenant may apply to the Land Court for an order for sale if the landlord fails to comply with the order or award mentioned in subsection (1)—

content.p: in a material regard, and
by the date specified in the order or award by virtue of section 84(2) or, as the case may be, section 61A(5) of the 1991 Act.
An “order for sale” is an order that the tenant has the right to buy the land comprised in the lease.

intro.p: The tenant must give notice of the application—

content.p: to the landlord,
where there is a heritable security over an interest in the land comprised in the lease, to the creditor who holds the security,
to such other persons as the Scottish Ministers may prescribe by regulations.

intro.p: Where—

content.p: the tenant acquired a right to buy the land comprised in the lease under section 28, and
the right to buy was extinguished under section 29(6) or 32(8),

wrapUp.p: the tenant may apply for an order for sale only if the period of 12 months, beginning with the date on which the right to buy was extinguished, has expired.

section.heading: Order for sale

intro.p: The Land Court may make an order for sale if satisfied that—
the landlord has failed to comply with the order or award mentioned in section 38A(1)—

content.p: in a material regard, and
by the date specified in the order or, as the case may be, the award,
the failure substantially and adversely affects the tenant's ability to fulfil the tenant's responsibilities to farm the holding in accordance with the rules of good husbandry,
greater hardship would be caused by not making the order than by making it, and
in all the circumstances it is appropriate.

The Land Court may make an order for sale despite the fact that the owner is subject to a legal incapacity or disability which would affect the owner's ability to transfer or otherwise deal with the land in respect of which the order is made.

intro.p: Where the owner is subject to an enforceable personal obligation to transfer the land to a person other than the tenant, the Land Court may not make an order for sale unless—

content.p: the transfer is a transfer mentioned in subsection (4), and

intro.p: the transfer—

content.p: is or forms part of a scheme or arrangement or is one of a series of transfers, and
the main purpose or effect, or one of the main purposes or effects, of the scheme, arrangement or, as the case may be, series is the avoidance of the making of an order for sale.

intro.p: The transfer referred to in subsection (3) is a transfer—

content.p: otherwise than for value,
between spouses in pursuance of an arrangement between them entered into at any time after they have ceased living together,
between companies in the same group, or

intro.p: in consequence of—

content.p: the assumption, resignation or death of one or more of the partners in a partnership, or
the assumption, resignation or death of one or more of the trustees of a trust.

For the purposes of subsection (4)(c), companies are in the same group if they are, or are included in a number of, companies which, by virtue of section 170 of the Taxation of Chargeable Gains Act 1992, together form a group for the purposes of sections 171 to 181 of that Act.

intro.p: The Land Court must give notice of the making of the order to—

content.p: the landlord,
the owner (where the owner is not the landlord),
where there is a heritable security over an interest in the land comprised in the lease, the creditor who holds the security,
the Keeper of the Registers of Scotland,
such other persons as the Scottish Ministers may prescribe by regulations.
In subsection (1)(b), what is good husbandry is to be construed by reference to schedule 6 of the Agriculture (Scotland) Act 1948.

intro.p: In this Part, “owner” includes a person in whom the land is vested for the purposes of any enactment relating to—

content.p: sequestration, bankruptcy, winding-up or incapacity, or
the purposes for which judicial factors may be appointed.

section.heading: Effect of order for sale: prohibition of transfer etc.

content.p: The Scottish Ministers may by regulations make provision prohibiting persons from transferring or otherwise dealing with land in respect of which an order for sale has been made under section 38B.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (1) may in particular include provision—

content.p: specifying the persons to whom the prohibition is to apply,
specifying the period during which the prohibition is to apply,
specifying transfers or dealings which are and are not prohibited by the regulations,

requiring information to be incorporated in deeds relating to the land (including specifying the information that is to be incorporated, the circumstances in which it is to be incorporated and the deeds in which it is to be incorporated),
requiring such information to be removed and the circumstances in which it is to be so removed.

section.heading: Effect of order for sale: suspension of rights

intro.p: Where an order for sale is made under section 38B, the rights mentioned in subsection (3) are—

content.p: suspended as from the date when the Land Court makes the order, and

intro.p: revived—

content.p: when a transfer by virtue of the order is completed, or

if such a transfer is not completed before the end of the period mentioned in subsection (2), or if the order for sale ceases to have effect, on the end of that period or on the order ceasing to have effect, whichever occurs first.

intro.p: The period referred to in subsection (1)(b)(ii) is whichever of the following periods ends later—

content.p: the period of 12 months beginning with the day on which notice under section 38E(3) is given, or
such longer period fixed by or agreed under section 38F(4) or, as the case may be, specified in an order under section 38I(4)(b)(ii).

intro.p: The rights referred to in subsection (1) are any rights—

content.p: of pre-emption, redemption or reversion, or
deriving from any other option to purchase,

wrapUp.p: exercisable over the land in respect of which the order for sale has been made.

content.p: The Scottish Ministers may by regulations make provision about the suspension and revival of other rights in or over land in respect of which an order for sale has been made.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (4) may in particular include provision specifying—

content.p: the rights to which the regulations do and do not apply,
the period during which such rights are suspended,
the circumstances in which the rights are revived (which may include the ending of a period as specified in the regulations).

intro.p: Nothing in this section—

content.p: affects the operation of an inhibition on the sale of the land,
prevents an action of adjudication from proceeding, or
affects the commencement, execution or operation of any other diligence.

section.heading: Tenant's right to buy

intro.p: Where—

content.p: an order for sale is made under section 38B, and

the period within which an appeal against the making of the order may be brought has expired without an appeal being brought or, where such an appeal has been brought, it has been abandoned or dismissed,

wrapUp.p: the tenant has the right to buy the land in respect of which the order has been made from the owner.

content.p: Where a tenant has a right to buy under subsection (1), the tenant may proceed in accordance with section 38F to buy the land from the owner provided that notice is given under subsection (3).

intro.p: Notice is given under this subsection if, before the period mentioned in subsection (4) has expired, the tenant gives notice that the tenant intends to buy the land to—

content.p: the owner,
the Keeper of the Registers of Scotland, and
the Land Court.

intro.p: That period is the period of 28 days beginning with—

content.p: the day after the last day on which an appeal may be brought (no appeal having been brought), or
an appeal having been brought, the day after the day on which the appeal was abandoned or dismissed.

intro.p: If at any time the tenant does not intend to proceed in accordance with section 38F to buy the land, the tenant must give notice of that fact to—

content.p: the owner,
the Keeper of the Registers of Scotland, and
the Land Court.

intro.p: Where the tenant—

content.p: does not give notice under subsection (3), or
gives notice under subsection (5),

wrapUp.p: the tenant's right to buy is extinguished.

section.heading: Procedure for buying

content.p: It is for the tenant to make the offer to buy in exercise of the tenant's right to buy under section 38E.

intro.p: The offer is to be at a price—

content.p: agreed between the tenant and the person from whom the land is to be bought (“the seller”), or

intro.p: where there is no such agreement—

content.p: payable by the tenant in accordance with section 34(8), or
if the price is determined in an appeal under section 37, as is so determined.
The offer must specify the date of entry and of payment of the price in accordance with subsection (4).

intro.p: The date of entry and of payment of the price are to be—

content.p: a date not later than 6 months from the date when the tenant gave notice under section 38E(3) of the tenant's intention to buy,

intro.p: where the price payable by the tenant is the subject of an appeal under section 37 which has not, before the expiry of the period of 4 months beginning with the date when the tenant gave such notice, been—

content.p: determined, or
abandoned following agreement between the tenant and the seller,

wrapUp.p: a date not later than 2 months after the appeal is so determined or, as the case may be, abandoned, or

content.p: such later date as may be agreed between the tenant and the seller.
The offer may include such other reasonable conditions as are necessary or expedient to secure the efficient progress and completion of the transfer.

intro.p: The seller must—

content.p: make available to the tenant such deeds and other documents as are sufficient to enable the tenant to proceed to complete title to the land,
transfer title accordingly.

section.heading: Appointment of valuer and valuation of the land

content.p: The provisions mentioned in subsection (2) apply to a sale implementing a tenant's right to buy by virtue of an order for sale as they apply to a sale implementing a tenant's right to buy under section 28, subject to the modifications mentioned in that subsection.

intro.p: Those provisions are—
section 33 (appointment of valuer), subject to the modifications that—

content.p: in subsection (2), the reference to section 29(2) or (4) is to be read as a reference to section 38E(3),
subsection (5) does not apply,

intro.p: section 34 (valuation of land), subject to the modifications that—

content.p: in subsection (1), the reference to the date of notice under section 26 of the seller's proposal to transfer the land is to be read as a reference to the date of notice under section 38E(3),
in subsection (8), the reference to section 32(2)(b)(i) is to be read as a reference to section 38F(2)(b)(i),
section 35 (special provision where buyer is general partner in limited partnership), subject to the modification that the reference to section 28 is to be read as a reference to section 38E,

intro.p: section 36 (further provision on valuation), subject to the modifications that—

content.p: in subsection (6)(a), the reference to section 32(7) is to be read as a reference to section 38I(3),

p.mod:
the following subsection is to be inserted after subsection (6)—
(6A)
Where—
(a)
the Land Court has made an order under section 38H(3),
(b)
the seller to whom the order applies has complied with the order, and
(c)
the tenant does not proceed with the purchase of the land from the seller,
the tenant is liable to the seller for any expenses met by the seller by virtue of subsection (5).
,

content.p: section 37 (appeal to the Lands Tribunal against valuation), subject to the modification that, in subsection (3)(b), the reference to section 32(2)(b)(ii) is to be read as a reference to section 38F(2)(b)(ii), and
section 38 (referral of certain matters by the Lands Tribunal to the Land Court).

section.heading: Failure of seller to complete transaction

intro.p: If the seller has not, within the period fixed by or agreed under section 38F(4)—

content.p: complied with section 38F(6)(a), or
done any of the things mentioned in subsection (2),

wrapUp.p: the tenant may apply to the Land Court for an order under subsection (3).

intro.p: The things are—

content.p: concluding missives for the sale of the land, or
taking all steps which the seller could reasonably have taken in the time available towards so concluding missives.

intro.p: An order under this subsection may—

content.p: direct the seller to comply with section 38F(6)(a) within such period as the order may specify,

intro.p: direct the seller—

content.p: to conclude missives, and
to take such remedial action for the purpose of so concluding missives,

wrapUp.p: within such period as the order may specify, and

content.p: direct the tenant and seller to incorporate into the missives any term or condition in respect of the sale of the land as the order may specify.

intro.p: If the seller fails to comply—

content.p: with an order under subsection (3), or
with section 38F(6)(b),

wrapUp.p: the Land Court may, on the application of the tenant, authorise its principal clerk to adjust, execute and deliver such deeds or other documents as will complete the transfer of ownership of the land to the tenant to the same force and effect as if done by the seller.

section.heading: Failure of tenant to complete transaction

content.p: If the tenant has not, within the period fixed by or agreed under section 38F(4), done any of the things mentioned in subsection (2), the seller may apply to the Land Court for an order under subsection (3).

intro.p: The things are—

content.p: concluding missives for the sale of the land, or
taking all steps which the tenant could reasonably have taken in the time available towards so concluding missives.

intro.p: An order under this subsection may—
direct the tenant—

content.p: to conclude missives, and
to take such remedial action for the purpose of so concluding missives,

wrapUp.p: within such period as the order may specify, and

content.p: direct the tenant and seller to incorporate into the missives any term or condition in respect of the sale of the land as the order may specify.

intro.p: The right to buy is extinguished if—

content.p: the tenant fails to comply with an order under subsection (3), or

intro.p: no order having been applied for under section 38H(3) or under subsection (3), missives have not been concluded before the end of—

content.p: the period of 12 months beginning with the date when the tenant gave notice under section 38E(3) of the tenant's intention to buy, or
such longer period as the Land Court may, on the application of the tenant, order.

section.heading: Completion of sale to tenant

content.p: The price paid for the transfer of ownership of the land to the tenant is to be paid not later than the final settlement date.
The “final settlement date” is the date on which the period, fixed or agreed under section 38F(4) or, as the case may be, specified in an order under section 38I(4)(b)(ii), expires.

intro.p: Where, on the final settlement date, the seller is not able to effect the grant of a good and marketable title to the tenant—

content.p: the price, or
if, for any reason, the price has not been ascertained, such sum as may be fixed by the valuer appointed under section 33,

wrapUp.p: is to be consigned into the Land Court until that title is granted, the tenant gives notice under section 38E(5) to the court of the tenant's decision not to proceed to complete the transaction or, as the case may be, the Land Court orders its release.

content.p: Except where subsection (3) applies, where the price remains unpaid after the date not later than which it is to be paid, the tenant's right to buy is extinguished.

Any heritable security which burdened the land immediately before title is granted to the tenant in pursuance of this section ceases to do so on the registration of that title in the Land Register of Scotland.
Where such a security also burdens land other than the land in respect of which title is granted to the tenant, the security does not, by virtue of subsection (5), cease to burden that other land.

Unless the creditors holding any such security otherwise agree, the tenant must pay to them according to their respective rights and preferences any sum which would, but for this subsection, be paid to the seller by the tenant as the price for the land.
Any sum paid by a tenant under subsection (7) is to be deducted from the sum which the tenant is to pay to the seller as the price for the land.
Any legal incapacity or disability of an owner has no effect on the title passed to a tenant to which land has been sold in accordance with this Part.

section.heading: Effect of extinguishing of right to buy

content.p: Where a right to buy is extinguished under section 38E(6), 38I(4) or 38J(4), the tenant may acquire a subsequent right to buy the same land or any part of it under section 28(1) but only if the conditions mentioned in subsection (2) are met.

intro.p: Those conditions are that—

content.p: the period of 12 months from the extinguishing of the right to buy under section 38E(6), 38I(4) or 38J(4) has expired, or

intro.p: before that period has expired—

content.p: the land is transferred to another person whether under an order for sale or otherwise, and
that person requires to give notice under section 26 in relation to a subsequent transfer.

section.heading: Sale to third party

content.p: This section applies where a tenant's right to buy land in respect of which an order for sale has been made is extinguished under section 38E(6), 38I(4) or 38J(4).

The tenant may, before the expiry of the period mentioned in subsection (3), apply to the Land Court for the order for sale to be varied to allow the land in respect of which the order has been made to be offered for sale on the open market.
That period is the period of 28 days beginning with the date on which the right to buy was extinguished.

intro.p: The tenant must give notice of the application—

content.p: to the owner,
where there is a heritable security over an interest in the land to which the application relates, to the creditor who holds the security,
to such other persons as the Scottish Ministers may prescribe by regulations.
The Land Court may, if it considers it appropriate in all the circumstances, grant the application and vary the order for sale to require the land to be offered for sale on the open market.

intro.p: Where—

content.p: no application is made under subsection (2), or
the Land Court refuses such an application,

wrapUp.p: the order for sale ceases to have effect.

section.heading: Procedure for sale to third party

content.p: The Scottish Ministers may by regulations make further provision about the sale of land in relation to which the Land Court has, under section 38L, varied an order for sale to allow the land to be offered for sale on the open market.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (1) may in particular include provision about—

content.p: the appointment of a person to sell the land,
the valuation of the land (including the appointment of a valuer, who need not be a different person to the person appointed to sell the land),
the procedure for the sale of the land (including sale by private bargain or by public roup),
the period within which the land is to be sold (including provision for applications to the Land Court to extend such a period),
the persons to whom the land cannot be sold,
the powers of the person appointed to sell the land, including powers to adjust, execute or deliver any deeds or other documents necessary to complete the transfer of ownership of the land,

intro.p: the duties of the person appointed to sell the land, which must include—

content.p: a duty to ensure that the price at which the land is sold is the best that can reasonably be obtained, and
a duty to compensate any person who incurs a loss caused as a result of the appointed person's negligence in the sale of the land,
the distribution of the proceeds of sale,
liability for any expenses incurred by the person appointed to sell or value the land,
reports by the person appointed to sell the land to the Land Court,
the effect on any rights such as are mentioned in section 38D(3),
the effect on any heritable securities which burden the land in respect of which the order for sale has been made,
what happens if the land is not sold within a period specified in the regulations.

Regulations under subsection (1) may apply the provisions of this Act, that apply to the sale of land comprised in a lease to a tenant by virtue of an order for sale, to the sale of such land on the open market, with or without modifications.
Regulations under subsection (1) may modify any enactment (including this Act).

section.heading: Restriction on notice to quit etc. where sale to third party

content.p: This section applies where a third party buys the land comprised in the lease of a 1991 Act tenancy by virtue of an order for sale varied under section 38L.

During the period of 10 years beginning with the date the third party acquired title to the land, sections 22 to 24, 26 and 43 of the 1991 Act have effect in relation to the tenancy subject to the following modifications.

intro.p: Section 22(2) has effect as if—

content.p: paragraphs (a) and (b) were omitted,

p.mod:
for paragraph (c) there were substituted—
(c)
the Land Court, on an application made—
(i)
by a landlord who bought the land constituting the tenancy by virtue of an order for sale varied under section 38L of the Agricultural Holdings (Scotland) Act 2003 Act,
(ii)
not more than 9 months before the giving of the notice to quit,
granted a certificate under section 26(1) that the tenant was not fulfilling the tenant's responsibilities to farm the holding in accordance with the rules of good husbandry,
, and

content.p: for “any of paragraphs (a) to (f)” there were substituted “any of paragraphs (c) to (f)”.

Section 24(1)(e) has effect as if, for “not falling within section 22(2)(b) of this Act”, there were substituted “and, in a case where the use requires permission under the enactments relating to town and country planning, such permission has been obtained”.

p.mod:
Section 26 has effect as if, after subsection (1), there were inserted—
(1A)
The Land Court must not grant a certificate under subsection (1) where subsection (1B) applies.
(1B)
This subsection applies where—
(a)
the application under subsection (1) is made by a landlord who bought the land constituting the tenancy by virtue of an order for sale varied under section 38L of the Agricultural Holdings (Scotland) Act 2003 Act (the “2003 Act”), and
(b)
the tenant's failure to farm in accordance with the rules of good husbandry is attributable to a material breach of the former landlord's obligations in relation to the tenant on the basis of which the Land Court made the order under section 84(1)(b) of the 2003 Act referred to in section 38A(1)(a) of that Act.
.

Section 43 has effect as if, for subsection (2), there were substituted—
(2)
Compensation is not payable under this section where—
(a)
the notice to quit relates to land being permanent pasture which the landlord has been in the habit of letting annually for seasonal grazing or of keeping in the landlord's own occupation and which has been let to the tenant for a definite and limited period for cultivation as arable land on condition that the tenant must, along with the last or waygoing crop, sow permanent grass seeds, or
(b)
the application of section 22(1) to the notice to quit is excluded by any of paragraphs (c) to (f) of subsection (2) of that section.
.

section.heading: Payment to former landlord where early resale

intro.p: This section applies where—

content.p: a tenant or, as the case may be, a third party (the “original buyer”) buys land under an order for sale made in respect of the land, and

intro.p: the land is subsequently sold—

content.p: before the end of the period of 10 years beginning with the date on which the original buyer acquired title to the land (the “original date”),
at a price higher than the price paid by the original buyer to the person from whom the land was bought (the “original seller”).

The original buyer must pay to the original seller a proportion of the difference between the price at which the land is subsequently sold and the price paid by the original buyer to the original seller.

intro.p: The proportion of the difference which must be paid to the original seller is to be—

content.p: 100 per cent where the subsequent sale occurs before the end of the period of 5 years beginning with the original date,
66 per cent where it occurs after the end of that period but before the end of the period of 8 years beginning with that date,
33 per cent where it occurs after the end of the period of 8 years beginning with that date.
The Scottish Ministers may by regulations make further provision about the payment that the original buyer must make to the original seller.

intro.p: Regulations under subsection (4) may in particular include provision about—

content.p: the exclusion, for the purposes of subsection (2), of so much of the price at which the land is subsequently sold as is attributable to an increase in the value of the land resulting from such causes as may be specified in the regulations (which may include improvements of the kind mentioned in schedule 5 of the 1991 Act),
payment where part only of the land bought under the order for sale is subsequently sold within the period of 10 years mentioned in subsection (1)(b),

the granting of standard securities over the land in relation to the liability to make a payment under this section (including the priority of such securities in relation to any other securities over the land),
circumstances in which no liability to make a payment under this section arises.

section.heading: Compensation

intro.p: Any person, including an owner or former owner of land comprised in the lease of a 1991 Act tenancy, who has incurred loss or expense—

content.p: in complying with the requirements of this Part following the making of an application by a tenant under section 38A(2) or 38L(2), or
where the tenant gave notice under section 38E(3) of the tenant's intention to buy the land, as a result of the failure of the tenant or the seller to complete the purchase,

wrapUp.p: is entitled to recover the amount of that loss or expense from the Scottish Ministers.

intro.p: The Scottish Ministers may by regulations make provision about—

content.p: the losses and expenses which may and may not be compensated,
the procedure for claiming compensation (including who determines whether compensation is payable),
the amount of compensation payable (including the manner in which such compensation is calculated).

Where, at the expiry of such period of time as may be fixed for the purposes of this subsection by regulations under subsection (2)(b), any question as to whether compensation is payable or as to the amount of any compensation payable has not been settled as between the parties, either of them may refer the question to the Lands Tribunal for Scotland.

section.heading: Use of land for non-agricultural purposes

intro.p: A—

content.p: 1991 Act tenancy; ...
tenancy under a lease constituting a limited duration tenancy,
tenancy under a lease constituting a modern limited duration tenancy, or
tenancy under a lease constituting a repairing tenancy,

wrapUp.p: does not cease to be such a tenancy by reason only that the land is used for a non-agricultural purpose.

content.p: Any term of the lease which prohibits the use of the land for a non-agricultural purpose is of no effect.

intro.p: Where—

content.p: subletting the land is prohibited (by the lease or otherwise); and
that prohibition impedes the use of the land for a non-agricultural purpose,

wrapUp.p: the tenant may, despite the prohibition, sublet the land provided that the purpose for which it is sublet is ancillary to the tenant’s use of the land for the non-agricultural purpose.

content.p: Subsections (1) to (3) do not apply if the use of the land for a non-agricultural purpose is otherwise than has been permitted under section 40 or 41.
In this section and sections 40 and 41, any reference to the land is a reference to the whole of the land comprised in the lease constituting the tenancy or any part of it.

section.heading: Notice of and objection to diversification

content.p: A tenant under a tenancy mentioned in section 39(1) who intends to use the land for a non-agricultural purpose must send a notice (in this section and in sections 40A and 41 referred to as a “notice of diversification”) to the landlord.

intro.p: The notice of diversification must be given in writing not less than 70 days before the date on which the tenant proposes to commence using the land for that purpose and must specify—

content.p: what the non-agricultural purpose is;
the land that would be used for that purpose;
any changes to the land the tenant proposes to effect for that purpose; and
the date on which the tenant proposes to commence using the land for that purpose,

wrapUp.p: and must address such matters as may constitute any ground of objection mentioned in subsection (9)(a)(i) to (iii).

intro.p: Where—

content.p: the tenant proposes to effect changes to the land for the non-agricultural purpose; or
the tenant’s intended use of the land for that purpose is in furtherance of a business,

wrapUp.p: the notice must also specify how the changes are, or, as the case may be, the business is (so far as relating to the land), to be financed and managed.

intro.p: Where a notice of diversification is given in accordance with subsections (2) and (3), and the landlord does not object to the notice, the land may be used—

content.p: for the purpose specified under paragraph (a), and as specified under paragraphs (b) and (c), of subsection (2); and
from the appointed date,

wrapUp.p: subject to any conditions imposed under subsection (10).

intro.p: For the purposes of subsection (4)(b), the appointed date is—

content.p: the date specified under subsection (2)(d);
where the landlord has made a request for information under subsection (6), the date falling 70 days from the making of the request, if later than the date so specified,
such earlier date as the landlord and tenant may agree to.

intro.p: Where the landlord objects to the notice of diversification, the land may be used for the purpose specified under paragraph (a), and as specified under paragraphs (b) and (c), of subsection (2)—
only if—

content.p: the landlord withdraws the objection,
the landlord does not apply under section 40A for a determination in relation to the objection, or
such an application having been made, the Land Court determines under section 41 that the objection is unreasonable,
from the relevant date, and

intro.p: subject to any conditions imposed—

content.p: by the landlord under subsection (14), or
by the Land Court under section 41(2) or (3).

intro.p: For the purposes of subsection (5A)(b), the relevant date is—
where no application is made under section 40A—

content.p: the date specified under subsection (2)(d),
if the objection is withdrawn, the date of the withdrawal,
the date the period mentioned in section 40A(3) expires,

wrapUp.p: whichever is the later,

content.p: where an application is made under section 40A, the date fixed by the Land Court under section 41(1)(b)(ii).
The landlord may, on one occasion within 30 days of the giving of the notice of diversification, request the tenant to provide the landlord with relevant information.

intro.p: For the purposes of subsection (6), information is relevant if it—
relates to—

content.p: the intended use of the land for the non-agricultural purpose (including any proposed changes to the land); and
where the intended use of the land is in furtherance of a business, the finance or management of the business; and
is necessary for the landlord’s consideration of whether or not there are grounds under subsection (9)(a)(i) to (iii) or (b) for objection to the notice of diversification.
The tenant is to provide any information reasonably requested under subsection (6) within 30 days of the date on which it was requested.

intro.p: The landlord may object to the notice of diversification if (and only if)—
the landlord reasonably considers that the intended use of the land for the non-agricultural purpose (including any proposed changes to the land) would—

content.p: lessen significantly the amenity of the land or the surrounding area;
substantially prejudice the use of the land for agricultural purposes in the future;
be detrimental to the sound management of the estate of which the land consists or forms part; or
cause the landlord to suffer undue hardship;

where the notice specifies a matter mentioned in subsection (3), the landlord reasonably considers that it fails to demonstrate that the proposed changes are, or, as the case may be, the business (so far as relating to the land) is, viable; or
the tenant has failed to comply with subsection (8).

Where the landlord does not object to the notice of diversification, the landlord may impose on the tenant any reasonable conditions in relation to the use of the land for the non-agricultural purpose (including in relation to any proposed changes to the land).

intro.p: The landlord is, within the period mentioned in subsection (12), to notify the tenant in writing—

content.p: of any objection to the notice of diversification (and the grounds for the objection) or, as the case may be, of the fact that the landlord does not object to the notice; and
where the landlord does not object to the notice, of any conditions imposed under subsection (10) (and the reasons for imposing them).

intro.p: The period is—

content.p: where the landlord has made a request for information under subsection (6), 60 days from the making of the request,
where the landlord has made no such request, 60 days from the giving of the notice of diversification.

If no notification is given in accordance with subsections (11) and (12), the landlord is, except where the non-agricultural purpose is the planting and cropping of trees, deemed not to have objected to the notice of diversification nor to have imposed any conditions in relation to use of, or changes to, the land.

intro.p: Where the landlord withdraws the objection under subsection (9) before the expiry of the period mentioned in section 40A(3), the landlord—

content.p: must notify the tenant in writing of the withdrawal, and

may impose any conditions as mentioned in subsection (10) and, where such conditions are imposed, must, at the same time as notifying the tenant of the withdrawal of the objection, notify the tenant in writing of the conditions (and the reasons for imposing them).

section.heading: Landlord's objection: application to Land Court

content.p: This section applies where the landlord gives notice of an objection under section 40(11)(a) to a notice of diversification.
The landlord may, before the expiry of the period mentioned in subsection (3), apply to the Land Court for a determination under section 41 that the objection is reasonable.
That period is 60 days from the giving of notice of the objection under section 40(11)(a).

intro.p: The objection ceases to have effect—

content.p: on the expiry of the period mentioned in subsection (3) unless the landlord applies, before the expiry of that period, to the Land Court under subsection (2), or
if it is withdrawn before the expiry of that period, no such application having been made.

section.heading: Imposition of conditions by Land Court

intro.p: Where , on an application made by the landlord under section 40A(2), the Land Court determines that an objection by the landlord to a notice of diversification is unreasonable—

content.p: the objection is of no effect; and

intro.p: the land may be used—

content.p: as mentioned in paragraph (a) of subsection (4) of section 40; and
from such date as the Court may fix,

wrapUp.p: subject to any conditions imposed under subsection (2).

content.p: Where, by virtue of subsection (1), the land may be used as mentioned in section 40(4)(a) or (5A) , the Land Court may impose on the tenant such reasonable conditions in relation to the use of the land as so mentioned as it considers appropriate.

intro.p: Where , on the application of the tenant, the Land Court determines that a condition imposed by the landlord under section 40(10) or, as the case may be, (14) is unreasonable, the Court may—

content.p: remove the condition; and
in its place, impose on the tenant such reasonable conditions as it considers appropriate.

section.heading: Tenant’s right to timber

intro.p: The tenant under—

content.p: a 1991 Act tenancy; ...
a limited duration tenancy,
a modern limited duration tenancy, or
a repairing tenancy,

wrapUp.p: has, for so long as the tenancy continues to have effect, the right to cut timber from any trees planted on the land by the tenant on or after the coming into force of this section; and any such timber belongs to the tenant.

content.p: Subsection (1) does not apply in so far as the lease or any agreement in writing between the landlord and tenant makes provision to the contrary, provided that the lease or agreement also includes provision for a reduction in rent or payment of compensation to the tenant in respect of any loss incurred by the tenant as a result of that contrary provision.

section.heading: Right to compensation for improvements

content.p: Subject to sections 48 and 49, a tenant of a short limited duration tenancy , a limited duration tenancy or a modern limited duration tenancy is entitled, on quitting the land on termination of the tenancy, to compensation from the landlord in respect of any improvement to which this subsection applies carried out by the tenant.
Subsection (1) applies to the improvements specified in Schedule 5 to the 1991 Act (that Schedule applying for the purposes of that subsection as it does for the purposes of that Act).

intro.p: Where an improvement is the improvement specified in paragraph 32 (laying down of temporary pasture) of that Schedule, the tenant is entitled to compensation under subsection (1) even if—

content.p: that improvement; or
the leaving of temporary pasture at the termination of the tenancy,

wrapUp.p: was in contravention of a term of the lease or any agreement made by the tenant as to the method of cropping the arable lands.

content.p: Where a tenant has remained in occupation of the land during two or more tenancies, the tenant is not deprived of any right to compensation under subsection (1) by reason only that the improvements were not carried out during the tenancy on the termination of which the tenant quits the land.

Nothing in any order made under section 73 of the 1991 Act which varies the provisions of schedule 5 to that Act affects the right of a tenant of a short limited duration tenancy, a limited duration tenancy or a modern limited duration tenancy to claim, in respect of an improvement made or begun before the date on which such order comes into force, any compensation to which, but for the making of the order, the tenant would have been entitled.

section.heading: Amnesty under the Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2016

content.p: A tenant under a short limited duration tenancy, a limited duration tenancy or a modern limited duration tenancy is entitled to compensation under section 45 if Chapter 8 of Part 10 of the Land Reform (Scotland) Act 2016 applies.

section.heading: Payment of compensation by incoming tenant

intro.p: Subsections (2) to (5) of section 35 (payment of compensation by incoming tenant) of the 1991 Act (as read with Schedule 5 to that Act) apply to compensation which is payable or has been paid to an outgoing tenant of a short limited duration tenancy , a limited duration tenancy or a modern limited duration tenancy by the landlord under section 45(1) of this Act as they do to compensation to which that section of that Act applies, but as if—

content.p: in subsection (4), paragraph (a) were omitted;
in subsections (4) and (5), the references to an agricultural holding and the holding were references to the land; and
in subsection (5), the words “a new” were read as “an”.

section.heading: Amount of compensation

content.p: The amount of compensation payable to a tenant under section 45(1) is such sum as fairly represents the value of the improvement to an incoming tenant.

intro.p: In ascertaining the amount of compensation so payable—

content.p: account is to be taken of any benefit which the landlord has agreed in writing to give the tenant in consideration of the tenant carrying out the improvement; and

intro.p: where a grant has been or will be made to the tenant in respect of the improvement, subject to the conditions of the grant—

content.p: if either the landlord or tenant has not made or will not make a contribution towards the cost of the improvement, or neither of them has made or will make such a contribution, the grant is not to be taken into account;

in any other case, there is to be taken into account such proportion of the grant as equals the proportion of any contribution made by the tenant towards the cost of the improvement as a proportion of the total of the tenant’s contribution added to that of the landlord.

In ascertaining the amount of any compensation payable by virtue of subsection (3) of section 45, account is to be taken of any injury to or deterioration of the land due to the contravention of the lease or agreement mentioned in that subsection (except insofar as the landlord has recovered damages in respect of the injury or deterioration).

section.heading: Consent required for compensation in certain cases

content.p: Compensation under section 45(1) is not payable for an improvement specified in Part I of Schedule 5 to the 1991 Act unless, before the improvement was carried out, the landlord consented to it in writing (whether unconditionally or upon terms agreed on between the parties).

section.heading: Notice required for certain improvements

content.p: Compensation under section 45(1) is not payable for an improvement specified in Part II of Schedule 5 to the 1991 Act unless the tenant gave notice in writing to the landlord specifying the tenant’s intention to carry out the improvement and the manner in which it was proposed to carry it out.

intro.p: In section 39 (approval of Land Court in certain cases) of the 1991 Act (as read with Schedule 5 to that Act), subsections (1) to (4) apply in relation to compensation under section 45(1) as they do in relation to compensation under Part IV of that Act but as if, in subsection (1) of that section—

content.p: the words “a new” were omitted;
the words “one month” read “60 days”; and
the reference to notice under section 38(3) of that Act were a reference to the notice mentioned in subsection (1) of this section.

section.heading: Compensation for disturbance

intro.p: Where—

content.p: any land is resumed under section 17; or
a short limited duration tenancy , a limited duration tenancy or a modern limited duration tenancy terminates by notice under subsection (3) of that section,

wrapUp.p: compensation for disturbance is payable by the landlord to the tenant.

intro.p: Subsections (3) to (6) of section 43 (compensation for disturbance) of the 1991 Act apply in relation to compensation payable under subsection (1) above as they do in relation to compensation payable under that section, but as if—

content.p: in those subsections, the references to the holding were references to the land;
